questions.prompt: Which datapath component is responsible for calculating the next instruction address?
questions.explanation: The PC adder (typically adds 4 to PC for sequential execution) calculates the next instruction address.

questions.prompt: In a single-cycle datapath, when is the register file written?
options: At the beginning of the cycle
During the middle of the cycle
At the end of the cycle (falling edge)
questions.explanation: The register file is written at the end of the cycle on the falling clock edge, after all computations are complete.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the sign-extend unit in the datapath?
questions.explanation: The sign-extend unit converts 16-bit immediate values to 32 bits by replicating the sign bit.

questions.prompt: How many read ports does a typical MIPS register file have?
questions.explanation: The MIPS register file has 2 read ports (for rs and rt) and 1 write port (for rd), supporting R-type instructions.

questions.prompt: Which multiplexer selects between immediate and register as the second ALU input?
questions.explanation: The ALUSrc multiplexer selects whether the second ALU operand comes from a register or the sign-extended immediate.

questions.prompt: What input does the main control unit use to generate control signals?
questions.explanation: The main control unit decodes the opcode (bits 31-26) to determine which control signals to assert.

questions.prompt: For an R-type instruction, what should the RegDst control signal be?
questions.explanation: R-type instructions write to rd (destination register), so RegDst=1 to select the rd field.

questions.prompt: Which control signal determines if data memory is written?
questions.explanation: MemWrite=1 enables writing to data memory, used by store instructions.

questions.prompt: The ALU control unit takes which inputs?
questions.explanation: The ALU control takes the ALUOp signal from main control and the funct field to determine the specific ALU operation.

questions.prompt: For a beq instruction, when is the branch taken?
options: When ALU result is zero (Zero flag = 1)
questions.explanation: beq branches when the two registers are equal, which the ALU determines by subtraction giving zero (Zero=1).

questions.prompt: What is the main advantage of multi-cycle design over single-cycle?
questions.explanation: Multi-cycle allows shorter clock periods because each cycle only needs time for one stage, not the longest instruction.

questions.prompt: In multi-cycle design, what is the purpose of the Instruction Register (IR)?
options: To store the next PC value
To hold the instruction being executed across cycles
questions.explanation: The IR holds the current instruction so it remains available throughout all cycles of execution.

questions.prompt: If CPI = 4 and clock rate = 500 MHz, how many instructions execute per second?
questions.explanation: Instructions/second = clock rate / CPI = 500 MHz / 4 = 125 million instructions per second.

questions.prompt: Which factor does NOT directly appear in the CPU performance equation?
questions.explanation: CPU time = Instructions × CPI × Clock period. Register count affects CPI indirectly but is not in the equation.

questions.prompt: In a multi-cycle FSM, what does each state typically represent?
options: A different clock cycle of execution
questions.explanation: Each state in the multi-cycle FSM represents one clock cycle of the instruction execution process.
